advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>We love this photo!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, 1981</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (OCT. 83)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH PICTURE (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture was used for promoting Educatel, a French private computing school.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983 </strong></font><br><blockquote>Probably the last advert made by T.I. in the UK</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Sharp 1211 advert from ILLEL, a french computer seller</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.spies.com/~aek/orphanage.html" target="_blank">The Minicomputer Orphanage</a> website</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of Junya Kubota </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"List your technical requirements, Hewlett-Packard is ready to answer"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A step toward the future" <br><br> Hmmmm.....</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FLYER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.peekandpoke.org" target="_blank">www.peekandpoke.org</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1978)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Orion Young for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, FEB 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NOT REALLY AN IMSAI!</strong></font><br><blockquote>In october 1979, the IMSAI company went bankrupt. The IMSAI brand name and the spare parts stock were sold to the <b>Fischer-Freitas</b> Company. <br><br> This 1982 advert shows a Z80 CP/M based computer Fisher-Freitas tried to sell with the IMSAI name, without success.<br><br> Fisher-Freitas is still selling original parts for the 8080 model! and continue maintaining a nice 8080 history web site (see the Web links section).</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>February 1983<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> For years, people have been trying to build a better Apple II.<br> It finally happened.<br> Meet the Apple IIe, an impressive new version of a most impressive machine.<br> The 'e' means enhanced. Which means a bundle of new features...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZELAND AD. (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> The renaissance machine is a "one-of-a-kind" system for the "one-of-a-kind" person who demands and will not settle for anything less than, the best.</font><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zeland</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8-PAGE US ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (SEPT. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The amazing TI-99/4A.<br> A computer for 1800fr"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8-PAGE US ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT(1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The calculator was sold with a very helpful manual (Calculator Decision-Making Sourcebook) giving step- by-step examples for the best techniques used for solving mathematical, statistical and scientific problems, as well as programming tips.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.1000bit.net" target="_blank">www.1000bit.net</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>

computer.description:
We are looking for information about this rare machine made by the German company EDS. It seems that only 320 machines of this type have been sold, mostly in Germany.
The inside was composed of a C64 mainboard, a built-in PSU and a dual 5.25" floppy disk drives. The enhanced keyboard had a numeric keypad.

item.description: CMD SuperCPU||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CMD SUPERCPU</strong></font><br><blockquote>The SuperCPU by Creative Micro Devices is an accelerator cartridge for the Commodore 64. It contains an W65C816S processor running at 20 MHz, providing 20 times the performance of the stock 6510 processor! CMD later added a SuperRAM Card option that could include up to 16 MB of additional memory. There is also a v2 version that offers native 128 mode support (also called SuperCPU/128). It is one of the most sought-after Commodore peripherals.<p class="petitgris">Thomas Conté</p></blockquote>

CMD RAMLink||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CMD RAMLINK</strong></font><br><blockquote>This RAM expansion unit by Creative Micro Devices was intended to be used as a RAM drive to accelerate disk access. It is externally powered, and thus will preserve the data even when the computer is turned off.<p class="petitgris">Thomas Conté</p></blockquote>

Floppy disk unit 1540-1541||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> FLOPPY DISK UNIT 1540-1541</strong></font><br><blockquote>It is connected to the C64 via a serial link.<br> It is very very slow and can store 170 kb per disk.</blockquote>

Quick Data Drive||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> QUICK DATA DRIVE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>Cheaper and faster than diskettes.</b> <br><br> This Quick Data Drive from Dean Electronics is dedicated to Commodore 64 and <$252$>Vic 20</a> systems. It uses a special tape called 'Wafer', of 16, 64 or 128 Kb capacity. This wafer was also used by a product marketed for the <$223$>Sinclair Spectrum</a>, called Wafadrive. Various tests proved that the Q.D.D. was approximately 20 times faster than a normal cassette recorder and 2 or 3 times faster than the Commodore 1541 disk drive. The reason : data transfer routines (called QOS) much more efficient than those of Commodore, and a file management operating system (FMU) much more modern and powerful. <br><br> The Q.D.D. is however not more than an advanced tape recorder using a magnetic tape, and the delay to access a specific file still remains higher than with a normal disk drive. Despite its qualities, the Q.D.D. did not meet success because most C64 software was sold on disks or tapes and users had to acquire both Commodore peripherals before investing in a third powerful storage system.</blockquote>

CMD HD-20|||20Mb hard-drive|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CMD HD-20</strong></font><br><strong>> 20Mb hard-drive</strong><br><blockquote>This is a hard drive for the C64 or 128. SWAP-Devicenumber-Buttons let the HD become drive 8 or 9. It can create sub-directories and partitions, including 1541 emulation.</blockquote>
Model 1525||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MODEL 1525</strong></font><br><blockquote>It can print all the semi graphic characters of the C64. (30 characters per second) </blockquote>

computer.keyboard: Typewriter type, 82 keys with 4 function keys and numeric keypad
computer.media: Cassette unit. 2 x 170 KB 5.25'' floppy disc drives
computer.name: C64 EDC
computer.ports: RGB (composite, chroma/luma and sound in/out), 2 x Joystick plugs, Cardridge slot, Tape interfarce (300 bps), Serial, User Port, TV RF output
computer.sound: 3 voices / 9 octaves, 4 waveforms (sound output through TV)
